fields.description:
After activating the JIRA Greenhopper plugin, and viewing the /secure/GreenHopper.jspa?decorator=admin admin link, I get a stacktrace: HTTP Status 404 - Could not execute action [GreenHopper]:Action 'GreenHopper' not found or could not be initialized: Class not found

java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Action 'GreenHopper' not found or could not be initialized: Class not found at com.atlassian.jira.config.webwork.JiraActionFactory$JiraPluginActionFactory.getActionImpl(JiraActionFactory.java:60) at webwork.action.factory.ScriptActionFactoryProxy.getActionImpl(ScriptActionFactoryProxy.java:54) at webwork.action.factory.XMLActionFactoryProxy.getActionImpl(XMLActionFactoryProxy.java:54) at 
...

A JIRA restart is required to clear this up.
fields.summary: Greenhopper plugin requires restart to activate

fields.description:
This can be misleading if we want to turn debug on and off based on these false copies.

If these copies serve to verify the patches are correct, we probably should verify that they match...
fields.summary: conf-log4j.properties and conf-log4j-test.properties are different from the runtime patched copies

fields.description: When creating new review, dropdown should have current project pre-selected. Should be probably done as jsp:include call.
fields.summary: Fix selectProject page when creating new review in Crucible

fields.description:
Plugins can have UpgradesTasks. To rememmber which upgradeTask was executed we store a number of last ran upgrade task  for each plugin.
When migrating studio to plugins2 we changed some pluginKeys. That will cause all upgrade tasks to re-run. 
- We need to figure out how to get right upgrade tasks running. 
- Maybe it's safe to re-run all upgrade tasks.
fields.summary: Changing pluginkey breaks upgrade task continuity

fields.description:
When you start crucible, upgrade task fails, but looking into configuration the plugin build number gets increased. 
When upgrade task fails no consequent upgrade tasks should be ran and previous build number should be kept.
fields.summary: Upgrade number gets increased even when upgrade task fails
Crucible upgrade tasks fails when crowd is not set up
Implement streams config on dashboard admin page
Fetch additional feed entries after aggregation on the client side

fields.description:
Here's a bit of feedback from Devoxx you might like to consider:

I had a couple of customers suggest that they needed a second type of developer account. The customers in question were commerical outfits developing FOSS and either providing services or dual licensing their products.

Frequently they'll have some random user contribute a good set of bug fixes or feature and based on the strength of that will invite them to become a team member. Those users normally accept but only a small number actually end up having the time to contribute. They might do a small amount of contributing at the start which might tail off, or they might never hear from them again.

What these customers would like to do is create a Developer-lite account where the dev can browse code and maybe commit a small amount of code / participate in a small number of reviews up to a limit and then upgrade their accounts to full developer status. Obviously they'd like these Developer-lite accounts to be very cheap because of the high turnover of such users and the uncertainty around whether these users will become committed developers or not.
fields.summary: Consider supporting causual/ad-hoc developers user types

fields.description:
Say I have projects /FOO and /BAR in Subversion, with /COMMON storing common code. Say I now fix a bug in /COMMON, and the commit message says "This fixes bugs FOO-123 and BAR-345".   This commit won't be picked up in FOO-123 or BAR-345's Source tab.

This is because in Studio each JIRA project is associated with one top-level Subversion directory, and looks for commits only in there.
fields.summary: Commits anywhere in Subversion should be linked to issues

In studio 1.5 we had fisheye header and footer imlemented by overriding fisheye's header.tag file. With upgrade to plugins2 we are not able to access plugin components in header.tag anymore. 

New header and footer should be implemented as separate servlet call included from header.tag.

fields.description: JIRA and Confluence both have interfaces to list the set-up application links and edit project links. Fisheye doesn't - the only way to see what's set up is through the REST URL (http://$host.jira.com/source/plugins/servlet/applinks/instance and http://$host.jira.com/source/plugins/servlet/applinks/projectlinks?key=$key ) or by inspecting config.xml.
fields.summary: No way to list or delete applinks or project links in Fisheye

fields.description:
JIRA's project page lets one specify the associated Confluence, Fisheye and Crucible projects:

!jira_projlinks.png!

The 'Synchronize' link is meant to make this association two-way.

If the synchronize fails for some reason, there is no indication in the web interface. The only hint that something is wrong is that the URL redirects to:

/secure/project/ViewProject.jspa?message=editprojectlinks.error.synchronize&pid=10181

instead of:

/secure/project/ViewProject.jspa?message=editprojectlinks.result.synchronized&pid=10181
fields.summary: Project link synchronisation fails silently

fields.description:
The Crowd Apache authz module caches permissions for 300s in Studio.  This means that any group changes in the SVN permission manager may take up to 5 minutes to appear.  I think we should have a warning in the page about this delay: Something like:

"Note: Subversion permission changes may take up to 5 minutes to take effect, due to caching".
fields.summary: SVN permission manager should warn that effects are not immediate

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Status as of 17 September 2014|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3C78B5| titleBGColor=#3C78B5| bgColor=#E7F4FA}
Hi everyone,
 
Thanks so much for your votes and comments on this issue.
 
Atlassian is working hard on Atlassian Connect, Atlassian's strategic integration platform enabling ecosystem vendors to develop add-ons for Atlassian Cloud (OnDemand). Atlassian Connect 1.0 [was released in March 2014|http://blogs.atlassian.com/2014/03/introducing-atlassian-connect-1-0/], and you can already get access to [more than 50 public add-ons today built using the platform|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/search?application=&category=&cost=&hosting=cloud&marketingLabel=].
 
Due to stability and scalability reasons, we will not bundle additional third party add-ons with our Cloud offerings. But you should feel free to contact the vendors of your favourite add-ons to let them know that you would like them to create a Cloud version of the add-on! We will do our best to work together with the vendor to satisfy this request.
 
Since we have no plans to bundle additional add-ons in Cloud, we are closing this issue.
 
Cheers,
Bartek
JIRA Product Management
bartek (at) atlassian (dot) com
{panel}

fields.description:
If I want to disable read access for all users, and remove all groups from the project's entry in the SVN Permission manager, I get the warning:

    * Granting no access will grant all users read access in FishEye.

!svnperm_wtf.png!

Pardon me? Granting no access means granting read access to _everyone_ via Fisheye?

Okay, I _technically_ see why: removing all groups in Fisheye causes it to use _default_ groups.  But users do not care.  The behaviour is totally nonsensical and should be fixed.

For instance, perhaps we could have a {{_nobody}} group in Crowd, containing no users and hidden in the group management interface, which is always given read access in Fisheye.
fields.summary: Cannot remove all access via SVN permission manager

fields.description:
Studio assumes that the Subversion top-level directory is equal to the project key. Thus the Studio JST project maps to the {{/svn/JST/trunk}} subversion directory.

That is a workable assumption for new projects, but what do we do when customers have existing Subversion repositories that don't conform?

One option is to use [dodgy scripts|http://search.cpan.org/~salva/SVN-DumpReloc-0.02/bin/svn-dump-reloc] to rewrite the top-level directory names. This is very, very non-optimal:
 - often there are references from one top-level directory to another (eg. in build systems), which renaming would break.
 - top-level directory names are sometimes long, and do not map obviously to a JIRA project key.
 - developers are used to the old names, which are more descriptive and generally better than project keys.

The better option is leave Subversion alone, and for Atlassian to manually reconfigure Fisheye to parse the original directory names.  The *only* thing stopping this from being an option is the SVN permission manager.  It generates a SVN {{authz}} file using the project key, regardless of how Fisheye is configured.

So I'd like to suggest that the SVN permission manager be modified to query Fisheye to find the actual configured path, and then use _that_ in the authz file.
fields.summary: SVN permission manager should use SVN path configured in Fisheye, not the project key
Re-write the createSettingsForKey() method in the JiraPluginSettingsFactory

fields.description:
Please put up a page for potential and existing JIRA Studio customers who are interested in having Bamboo integration. It doesn't have to be too detailed, just an outline will do. You're able to use this as a basis:

Great to hear that you're interested in using Bamboo as part of JIRA Studio! There are no immediate plans for this, but it is a longer term goal for Studio to include Bamboo support if feasible. We are currently waiting for the release of 'elastic' Bamboo instances based on Amazon EC2, and once this is complete, we can investigate a timeline for adding full integration.

In the meantime, you are still able to have your JIRA Studio instance integrate with an independently-hosted Bamboo instance. This requires purchasing an installed Bamboo license and arranging for a hosting provider. An example provider is Contegix, who are a licensed reseller of Atlassian licenses and able to offer dedicated hosting. Please contact Contegix at sales@contegix.com for pricing and details.
fields.summary: Outline how JIRA Studio customers can integrate with an independently-hosted Bamboo instance

fields.description:
Studio has hardcoded 'users' , 'developers', 'administrators' and 'system-administrators' groups.   This is fine for new Studio instances, but very painful when hooking Studio up to an existing Crowd instance, which has its own groups.  For instance on studio.atlassian.com and labs.atlassian.com, whenever we create a new project, we then need to go to Fisheye, SVN and Confluence and change the groups.

It would be great if the default group names could be overridden by system properties. Eg. -Dstudio.role.developers=atlassian-dev
fields.summary: Allow overriding of default group names

fields.description:
(Raised upstream as [STRM-159|http://developer.atlassian.com/jira/browse/STRM-159])

A typical set of Confluence page edits will result in an activity stream item like this:

Joe Bloggs edited Home making:
1 change
4 changes
2 changes

Where the numbers link to the Confluence app with URLs like /pages/viewpreviousversions.action?pageId=4849733

In Confluence 2.10 at least, these links all take one to the same history overview page with checkboxes for each version:

This is quite useless. The link should take one to the actual diff page showing the change made.

fields.description:
As discovered today, Contegix's license updating scripts can put a bad license on a Studio instance.  With the new version of JIRA, this stops issues from being created.  Rather than doing that, it would be better to allow issues to be created, email the error, but still block users from being created, as it's a problem that needs to be fixed, and blocking users being created is not as severe as issues.

These issues will be fixed completely when JIRA uses the new license API, so that Studio doesn't have to load the license from disk.
fields.summary: Invalid license stops users from creating new issues

fields.description:
Take AOD-859 as an example. This issue required changes to both JST code and SAL code. When you look at the ticket for AOD-859 only the code commit against JST is shown. In this case the SAL code really is important for the issue and should be displayed alongside the JST code.

The Gdansk team is also affected by this issue, and I can only assume that if we're seeing this problem more frequently, then so are customers.

fields.description:
JIRA projects have an associated URL.  Eg. say we have a WEBSITE project: it's project URL might be http://www.atlassian.com.

In Studio, if this project URL is set, the URL is sometimes used as the project drop-down link, but sometimes not:

 - On /secure/Dashboard.jspa the project URL (http://www.atlassian.com) is used as the drop-down's link.
 - If a project from the drop-down is selected (is the 'in scope' project appearing in the drop-down), then the links to other projects use the JIRA URL (/browse/WEBSITE).
 - On /wiki/dashboard.action the JIRA URL (/browse/WEBSITE) is used.

I would think that the project URL should never be used in the project drop-down.  I am on JIRA, and see "Website" in the drop-down: I expect to be taken to the JIRA project (/browse/WEBSITE), not http://www.atlassian.com).  Let the project URL be used purely as a value for the "Home" tab.
fields.summary: JIRA project URL used inconsistently in project drop-down
